text.p: These are the leading stories in the Pakistani press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Twelve Pakistan Muslim League (PML) candidates were elected unopposed to the Senate (upper house), after scrutiny of nomination papers for 46 seats was completed.
- Another earthquake of mild intensity jolted Sibi and some other areas in Pakistan's southwestern Balochistan province.
- Pakistan has been listed by the United States among the major money-laundering countries of the world.

- The Mohajir National Movement (MQM) has told the federal government that as soon as its nominee for the post of governor Sindh province is announced, its nominated members will take oath in the provincial and federal cabinets.
- Former caretaker defence minister Shahid Hamid is likely to be named governor of Punjab province.
- The government has told Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) management to make the airline cost-efficient.
- Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif has abolished the existing facility of medical treatment abroad at state expense for all public representatives and government officers.
- The U.S. banking authorities have allowed Pakistani banks to open accounts and accept donations and deposits for Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's debt retirement scheme.
- Leading business houses have assured Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif they would offer financial support to the new government to help address problems such as low foreign exchange reserves.
- Pakistan, aligning itself with the global market-place, has reverted to a Sunday weekend for the first time in two decades.
- Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz said Pakistan's credit rating will improve within a year as a result of the PML's economic management policies.
- The State (central) Bank of Pakistan has established an information and transaction procedure for banks receiving money under the Prime Minister's debt retirement programme.

- Foreign investment inflows into the Karachi Stock Exchange in just three weeks have amounted to 777.743 million rupees ($20 million) mainly owing to the end of political uncertainty and expectations of higher corporate earnings in 1997.

- The bond market is moving at a snail's pace. In the last two years, only 1.96 billion rupees of term finance certificates were floated because of the 10 perent overall investment limit imposed on provident funds and other institutions.
